--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Thanks to b=
oth of you for looking into the issue.
> 
> I noticed that the current code=
 (with the random choice line inside
the loop
> as Jason and I discussed) c=
hooses each link at random from either
parent in
> proportion to the parent=
's fitness. Is that how the updated code
will work
> too?
>

Yes the update=
d code will work by randomly choosing a gene from one or
the other parent w=
hen there are matching genes (i.e. genes with the
same historical marking).=
  It will use the proportional probability
method.  

Note that the proport=
ional method is slightly different than past
versions of NEAT.  For example=
, my code would choose one gene
completely randomly regardless of fitness. =
 However, for disjoint
genes, my code would only include them from the more=
 fit parent. 
Jason's has a chance of including it from the less fit one.
 =

These differences however are subtle and should not matter much.  The
main=
 point is that yes it is multipoint (i.e. uniform) crossover.

(More answer=
s below)

> If so, it strikes me that might really slice up building blocks=
. To take
> P-NEAT, which is easier to think about, if one neural module ex=
isted
in a
> region of the substrate, and a different neural module existed=
 in
the same
> region in a parent, instead of possibly grabbing the whole m=
odule
from one
> parent and sticking it in a new genetic background, crosso=
ver would
take a
> few links from the modules of each of the parents and se=
e if they work
> together. 
> 
> To use a nice metaphor Ken has used before=
, in crossover you want to
swap a
> hand for a hand instead of take a hand =
and put it where an ear
belongs. This
> system is at least swapping parts o=
f hands for parts of hands, but it
> (almost) never allows an *entire* hand=
 to be placed on a new body.
Instead,
> it sees if taking x% of phenotypic =
slices from one hand works in
combination
> with 100-x% of phenotypic slice=
s from the other hand.
> 
> I hope that makes sense.
> 
> This is very simi=
lar to the question in GAs of using uniform (swapping
> slices of hands) vs=
. one- or two-point crossover (potentially swapping
> entire hands). 
> 
> =
A few questions
> 1) does canonical NEAT use the uniform version of crossov=
er or something
> like two-point crossover?
> 2) does the version of HyperN=
EAT you are about to release use uniform or
> two-point?
> 3) if the answer=
 to 1 is 'uniform', has anyone ever looked at trying
> something like two-p=
oint?
> 
> 
> 

(1) Yes it does use uniform.  I also included a more tradit=
ional
singlepoint crossover operator in my version of NEAT, but I never use=

it and as far as I know, no one else uses singlepoint crossover with
NEAT =
either.

2) HyperNEAT C++ will also use uniform.

3) As I mentioned, I did =
implement singlepoint crossover (is that what
you mean by two-point?).  And=
 I have tested it.  The reason I stopped
using it and turned its probabilit=
y of happening to zero in the
distribution is because it does not work as w=
ell as uniform types of
crossover in NEAT.  However, of course anyone can t=
urn it on again if
they wanted to, though I would not recommend it.

There =
are a couple reasons that singlepoint crossover in NEAT makes
less sense. F=
irst, my feeling is the building blocks hypothesis
doesn't make as much sen=
se with NEAT, so I don't think those analogies
really work when reasoning a=
bout its crossover operator.  Because
crossover almost always happens betwe=
en individuals in the same
species, they do not have totally separate modul=
es representing
different things.  That is, you are not looking at things l=
ike one
organism with wings and one with arms.  Such exotic difference are
=
likely to exist only beyond species boundaries, where NEAT rarely mates.

I=
nstead, mating in NEAT, like in nature, is between individuals with
general=
ly similar genes that represent generally similar "body plans."
 So when I =
talk about alignment issues, I am speaking on a
gene-by-gene basis, not a m=
odule-by-module basis, because generally
insofar as there are modules, they=
 are shared by those who are mating.

Then what is crossover doing in NEAT?=
  I think it may be more like the
way they talk about crossover in ES liter=
ature, where it can be a kind
of error-correction mechanism.  If someone ge=
ts a bad version of some
gene, mating can in effect flush it out over time =
by replacing it with
the good version from the other parent, which will eve=
ntually
proliferate over the population.  That is why I think crossover onl=
y
has a modest effect on performance in NEAT in general.  It's not a big
in=
novator.

In fact, I am somehat skeptical of the building blocks hypothesis=
 with
respect to mating in GAs in general, but that is a broader topic. 
Wh=
en it comes to NEAT, in any case, it doesn't really work that way.

Second,=
 genes NEAT genomes are actually ordered from oldest to newest
gene, which =
makes singlepoint crossover have a strange meaning:  It
means, in effect, t=
ake all the older genes from one parent and all the
newer genes from the ot=
her and concatenate them.  Intuitively I don't
see a really useful reason t=
o do that.

ken
